heroDescription: Global Insurance • A$30.2B Mkt Cap • COR 91.9% FY25
heroCompanyDescription: QBE Insurance Group (ASX: QBE) is one of the world's largest insurers, operating across 27 countries with a diversified portfolio spanning commercial, specialty, and crop insurance. Headquartered in Sydney, QBE reported FY25 NPAT of US$2,157M (+21%) with a combined operating ratio (COR) of 91.9% — ahead of its 93-95% guidance — marking the strongest underwriting performance in a decade. Gross written premium grew 7% to approximately US$22.3B, underpinned by disciplined pricing across North America, Europe, and Pacific.

skew.rationale: FY25 results delivered materially ahead of guidance with COR of 91.9% vs 93-95% target. The investment portfolio is benefiting from structurally higher interest rates (4.9% return on US$28.9B portfolio), and DPS increased 25%. The key risk is that catastrophe losses and a softening premium cycle could erode gains, but the current underwriting discipline and balance sheet strength support the bull case.

verdict.text: QBE's FY25 result on 20 February 2026 was a material beat: COR of 91.9% versus 93-95% guidance, NPAT of US$2,157M (+21%), and DPS up 25%. The investment portfolio delivered a 4.9% return on US$28.9B in assets, contributing US$1,633M. The stock rallied 8.6% on the day. At 12.0x trailing P/E with a 4.3% yield, QBE screens as reasonably valued if the hard market and investment income tailwinds persist. The central risk is that natural catastrophe losses above the US$751M incurred in FY25 would challenge the thesis, as would a softening in commercial insurance pricing.

featuredRationale: FY25 COR of 91.9% beat 93-95% guidance, NPAT US$2,157M (+21%), and DPS +25%. Hard market pricing and high-rate investment income sustain the bull case at 12x P/E.

identity.overview: QBE Insurance Group is one of the world's 20 largest general insurers and reinsurers, operating across three divisions: North America, International (Europe, Emerging Markets), and Pacific (Australia, New Zealand). The business writes commercial, specialty, and crop insurance with a deliberate focus on profitable underwriting discipline. FY25 was a landmark year: the 91.9% COR represents the strongest underwriting performance since the pre-2011 catastrophe period, and the 4.9% investment portfolio return reflects the structural benefit of US rates remaining at elevated levels. QBE's strategic priority is sustaining COR below 94% through the underwriting cycle while growing GWP by 5-7% annually.

hypotheses.title: T1: Hard Market Sustains COR <94%
hypotheses.description: Commercial insurance pricing remains above long-run loss cost trends across QBE's key geographies. QBE sustains COR below 94% for a second consecutive year, and the market re-rates the business as a consistently profitable insurer rather than a cyclical capital destroyer.
requires: Commercial insurance pricing in North America and International remains +3-5% above loss trend
Natural catastrophe losses remain within the US$750-900M corridor for FY26
No major reserve strengthening events across the North American portfolio
Australian commercial insurance market maintains current pricing discipline
Crop insurance (US) delivers within normalised range
supporting: Filings: FY25 COR of 91.9% beat 93-95% guidance by ~200bps — the largest positive COR surprise in five years
Corporate: CEO Andrew Horton confirmed pricing above loss cost trend in North America and International in FY25 result commentary
Competitor: Global peers (Zurich, Allianz, Chubb) reporting similar margin expansion, confirming systemic hard market rather than QBE-specific
Economic: Social inflation and claims severity trends easing in US liability lines, reducing the pressure on loss ratios
Filings: FY25 GWP growth of +7% with margin expansion demonstrates pricing above cost — not just volume-driven growth
contradicting: Academic: Insurance pricing cycles are mean-reverting; periods of outperformance attract capital and erode margins (average hard market lasts 3-5 years)
Economic: US motor and property insurance saw new capital entering in 2025 — early sign of market softening in personal lines
Filings: North America COR in FY24 was materially elevated; one bad cat year could push FY26 COR above 95%
Competitor: Swiss Re and Munich Re flagging moderating reinsurance pricing from 2025 renewals

hypotheses.title: T2: Investment Portfolio Outperforms
hypotheses.description: QBE's US$28.9B investment portfolio — predominantly investment-grade fixed income — continues to benefit from the structural reset to higher interest rates. As the portfolio rolls over into higher-yielding bonds, investment income exceeds consensus expectations and provides a durable earnings tailwind that cushions underwriting volatility.
requires: US Federal Reserve holds rates above 4% for the majority of FY26
No material credit impairments or defaults in the bond portfolio
QBE maintains conservative portfolio duration strategy (not extending duration into rate cut cycle)
Equity and alternative asset allocation avoids major mark-to-market losses
supporting: Filings: FY25 investment return of 4.9% on US$28.9B = US$1,633M contribution — largest investment income in QBE's modern history
Economic: US Fed Funds rate remains above 4% entering 2026; portfolio reinvestment at elevated yields continues
Corporate: QBE management confirmed 80%+ of portfolio in investment-grade fixed income, well-positioned for sustained elevated rate environment
Competitor: Peer insurers (AIG, Travelers) reporting similar investment income acceleration — systemic tailwind not QBE-specific
contradicting: Economic: Consensus expects 1-2 Fed rate cuts in 2026, which would moderate reinvestment yields over time
Academic: Insurance investment portfolios have average durations of 3-5 years; rate cuts would take time to reduce income but reduce unrealised gains
Filings: Equity and alternatives (US$2-3B) could face volatility in risk-off scenarios

hypotheses.title: T3: Catastrophe Season Overwhelms Rate Gains
hypotheses.description: A severe North American hurricane season or an above-budget catastrophe year drives QBE's COR above 97%, eliminating underwriting profit and eroding the investment income buffer. The stock de-rates as the market reassesses the sustainability of the hard market thesis.
requires: North Atlantic hurricane season above historical averages (US cat budget exceeded by >30%)
Secondary perils (flooding, severe convective storms, Australian bushfires) accumulate above budget
QBE's net cat retention of US$750-800M is exhausted by Q3 FY26
Reserve releases from prior years do not offset calendar-year cat losses
supporting: Economic: Climate change is increasing the frequency and severity of secondary perils (flooding, wildfires) which are harder to model and price
Academic: North Atlantic hurricane activity correlated with La Niña patterns; 2026 season models show elevated risk
Filings: QBE's FY25 cat losses of US$751M (4.1% ratio) were within budget — but budget exceeded in 3 of the prior 5 years
Competitor: Reinsurers flagging elevated catastrophe model uncertainty for North American perils
contradicting: Filings: QBE has materially improved its catastrophe hedging and retrocession programme since 2017-2019 losses
Corporate: QBE's crop insurance underwriting is disciplined; does not take concentrated agricultural peril exposure
Economic: Hard market pricing in cat-exposed lines has repriced significantly above loss cost trends — creating margin buffer
Filings: FY25 COR of 91.9% implies ~5% of premium budget for catastrophe events before COR exceeds 97%

hypotheses.title: T4: Premium Cycle Reversal / North America Deteriorates
hypotheses.description: The global commercial insurance market softens faster than expected as new capital enters post-hard-market. QBE's North American operations — historically the most volatile segment — return to COR above 100%, eroding group profitability. Combined with a rate cut cycle reducing investment income, the investment case unravels.
requires: Commercial insurance pricing turns negative in North America and International by H2 FY26
New capital entry (ILS, insurer start-ups) materially exceeds claims cost growth
QBE's North America COR returns above 100% in FY26 or FY27
Fed rate cuts reduce investment portfolio yield below 4.0%
Reserve development from US casualty (long-tail) lines proves adverse
supporting: Academic: Insurance cycles are mean-reverting; peak profitability attracts capital; average underwriting cycle is 5-7 years
Competitor: New Lloyd's of London syndicates forming in high-margin specialty lines
Economic: US casualty insurance reserve adequacy concerns have re-emerged across the industry (social inflation)
Filings: QBE's North America has been the most volatile segment historically; FY20-21 saw losses >US$500M
contradicting: Filings: FY25 North America COR improved materially year-on-year; management has restructured the portfolio since 2020
Corporate: QBE exited loss-making lines (US run-off, LMI) in 2020-2023 — the problematic portfolio has been remediated
Economic: US construction, energy, and specialty lines pricing remains above loss trend
Competitor: Global peers have not yet signalled meaningful softening in commercial or specialty lines

narrative.theNarrative: QBE is experiencing its best underwriting performance in over a decade, and the FY25 result has validated the multi-year transformation thesis. The narrative has shifted from "QBE is a serial earnings disappointment" to "QBE is a beneficiary of the hard market and rate cycle." At A$21.78, the stock trades at 12x trailing earnings with a 4.3% yield — undemanding for an insurer with a 91.9% COR and a US$28.9B investment portfolio generating 4.9% returns. The bear case requires a bad catastrophe year, a faster-than-expected premium cycle reversal, or US casualty reserve deterioration — all of which are plausible but not currently base case.

priceImplication.label: Embedded Assumptions at A$21.78
priceImplication.content: Hard market durability: Market assumes commercial pricing remains above loss trend through FY26. Investment income sustains: US rates remain elevated; portfolio reinvestment at 4.5-5.0% yields assumed. No reserve surprises: North American casualty run-off is fully reserved. Disciplined capital management: DPS growth of 20-25% pa assumed to continue. No above-budget cat year: FY26 natural catastrophe losses remain within the US$750-900M corridor.

narrative.evidenceCheck: The operational evidence is uniformly positive coming out of FY25: COR beat, GWP growth, DPS increase, and investment income at record levels. The structural bear case remains the insurance cycle — premium markets soften, capital re-enters, and margins compress. The academic literature on insurance cycles is clear that hard markets do not persist indefinitely. However, QBE's current underwriting quality and balance sheet strength suggest the cycle has further to run. The key discriminating variable for 2026 is catastrophe season performance.
narrative.narrativeStability: Conditionally stable, skewed upside. The FY25 beat has materially improved market confidence in QBE's underwriting discipline. The narrative is stable as long as: (1) no above-budget catastrophe season in 2026; (2) commercial insurance pricing holds; (3) investment income continues to benefit from elevated rates. A severe North Atlantic hurricane season or rapid Fed rate cuts would destabilise the narrative. The 12-month window to the next full-year result is the key holding period.

evidence.intro: Ten evidence domains assessed across QBE's FY25 result, industry dynamics, and portfolio risk. The operational and financial evidence is strongly positive; the key risks are structural (insurance cycle) and exogenous (catastrophe season).

cards.title: 1. Corporate Communications
cards.finding: QBE's FY25 results presentation (20 February 2026) was unambiguously positive. CEO Andrew Horton highlighted: (1) COR of 91.9% versus 93-95% guidance — "ahead of expectations"; (2) GWP growth of +7% with pricing discipline maintained; (3) DPS increased 25%; (4) investment portfolio return of 4.9% on US$28.9B. Management reiterated FY26 COR guidance of 93.5-95.5%, implying the market should not extrapolate FY25's outperformance. Key strategic messages: portfolio quality improvement is structural (not cyclical), crop insurance business is well-managed, and North America has been repositioned since 2020. Management was careful not to commit to sustained outperformance against the COR target.
cards.tension: Management guidance of 93.5-95.5% COR for FY26 — wider than FY25 actual — signals caution about natural catastrophe variability. There is a potential tension between the market's expectation (COR sustains below 93%) and management's explicit guidance (return toward the mid-range). The 25% DPS increase may have been ahead of consensus expectations, suggesting management confidence in cash generation.
cards.source: QBE FY25 Results Announcement; ASX Release 20 February 2026; Investor Presentation

cards.title: 2. Regulatory Filings & Financial Statements
cards.finding: FY25 headline financials (statutory): NPAT US$2,157M (+21% YoY), COR 91.9% (FY24: ~93.8%), GWP approximately US$22.3B (+7%), net earned premium approximately US$14.6B, investment income US$1,633M (return 4.9% on US$28.9B portfolio). Natural catastrophe losses US$751M (4.1% of NEP). Balance sheet: QBE maintains an A-rated balance sheet (S&P: A+), APRA Prescribed Capital Amount (PCA) coverage ratio above 1.7x. Dividend per share increased 25% year-on-year. Segment breakdown: North America, International (Europe, Emerging Markets), and Pacific all contributed to COR improvement. North America COR — historically the most volatile — improved meaningfully from FY24.
cards.tension: APRA's increased capital requirements for Australian insurers (post-2024 regulatory review) create some capital efficiency pressure. The statutory accounts will contain more granular segment data that may reveal concentration of underwriting performance. Reserve releases vs. additions in North American casualty (long-tail) lines are the most important audit figure to scrutinise.
cards.source: QBE FY25 Results; ASX Release 20 February 2026; APRA insurance industry statistics

cards.title: 3. Broker Research
cards.finding: Broker consensus is bullish post-FY25 beat. Of approximately 13 covering analysts: 8 Buy, 4 Hold, 1 Sell. Average 12-month price target approximately A$24.00-24.50, implying ~10% upside from A$21.78. Post-results, multiple brokers upgraded estimates and price targets following the COR beat. Bull case (Macquarie, UBS, JPMorgan): hard market is durable, investment income tailwind is structural at elevated rates, North America transformation is complete. Bear case (one sell-rated broker): valuation already reflects FY25 outperformance; FY26 management guidance (93.5-95.5% COR) implies mean reversion; insurance cycle risk underappreciated. Morningstar fair value: approximately A$21.00-22.00, suggesting stock is near fair value at current levels.
cards.tension: Analyst consensus is unusually constructive for a stock that has just rallied +8.6% on results. This suggests the fundamental case is improving rather than the stock being over-extended. However, with the target price of ~A$24 only ~10% above current levels, the reward-risk from current price is moderate rather than compelling.
cards.source: Macquarie Equities; UBS Research; JPMorgan; Morningstar; consensus data February 2026

cards.title: 4. Competitor & Industry Data
cards.finding: Global commercial insurance hard market remains intact but moderating. QBE's global peers — Chubb, AIG, Zurich, Allianz, Lloyd's of London syndicates — are all reporting combined ratio improvement driven by pricing above loss trend. Lloyd's of London posted its strongest calendar year COR on record in 2025. Reinsurance pricing remains firm at January 2026 renewals, with catastrophe excess-of-loss layers up 5-8%. However, there are early signs of moderation: (1) new Lloyd's managing agencies approved in 2025 for peak-priced specialty lines; (2) ILS (Insurance-Linked Securities) issuance at record US$20B+ in 2025, bringing new capacity to cat risk. Australian commercial market: pricing discipline maintained; SME and specialty lines +3-5% in FY25.
cards.tension: The competitive data is broadly constructive for FY26 but reveals a market approaching the peak of the hard cycle. Capital is returning to the reinsurance market — a structural precursor to softening. The 2026 reinsurance renewals (January) were firmer than feared, but the trend direction is toward moderation.

tags.text: Supports T1 (hard market holds in FY26)

cards.source: Lloyd's of London annual results; Chubb Q4 FY25; Swiss Re sigma report; Guy Carpenter renewal commentary

cards.title: 5. Economic Data
cards.finding: Two countervailing macroeconomic forces: (1) Higher US interest rates are structurally positive for QBE's investment income — the US Fed Funds rate above 4% since 2023 has materially lifted reinvestment yields on QBE's US$28.9B bond portfolio; (2) US social inflation and claims cost escalation in liability/casualty lines continues to challenge loss ratio management. Catastrophe modelling: 2026 North Atlantic hurricane season models (Colorado State University, Tropical Storm Risk) currently show elevated risk due to warm sea-surface temperatures and La Niña conditions. AUD/USD dynamics: QBE reports in USD but has significant AUD-denominated costs; AUD weakness in 2025 was modestly beneficial to USD-denominated results.
cards.tension: The macro environment is net positive for QBE in 2025-2026 (elevated rates + hard market) but both tailwinds are expected to moderate: consensus forecasts 1-2 Fed rate cuts in 2026, and the insurance cycle will eventually turn. The key question is timing — how long do these tailwinds persist?

tags.text: Supports T1 (social inflation creating pricing justification)

cards.source: US Federal Reserve rate decision data; Colorado State University seasonal hurricane forecast; ABS exchange rate data; Swiss Re Institute sigma

cards.title: 6. Alternative Data
cards.finding: Cat bond market pricing is informative. Insurance-Linked Securities (ILS/cat bond) spreads widened significantly after the 2023 Turkey earthquake and 2024 US hurricane season, reflecting reinsurance scarcity — supportive for primary insurers (QBE) who benefit from tighter reinsurance market pricing. Cat bond issuance at record US$20B+ in 2025 signals capital seeking to enter the high-return cat risk space. Commercial property rates index (CIAB survey): US commercial lines pricing remained positive in Q3-Q4 2025 at +3.5-5.5%. Aon's Global Insurance Market Insights: confirms the hard market remains intact but peaked in certain lines. Claims frequency data (Australian motor, commercial property): no adverse emerging trends in QBE's domestic book.
cards.tension: The cat bond issuance surge suggests capital is actively seeking to compete with traditional reinsurers — a leading indicator of eventual market softening, even if the direct impact on QBE's primary insurance margins is lagged by 12-18 months.
cards.source: Artemis.bm ILS market data; CIAB commercial insurance pricing survey; Aon Global Market Insights Q4 2025

cards.title: 7. Academic Research
cards.finding: Insurance cycle literature is the key theoretical framework. Published research (Harrington & Danzon; Cummins & Weiss) establishes that: (1) underwriting cycles are systematic and persistent, driven by capacity shocks and information asymmetries; (2) COR mean-reversion takes 3-7 years after a hard market peak; (3) investment income serves as a partial buffer but does not eliminate underwriting cycle risk. Catastrophe loss literature: climate change is increasing the frequency of secondary perils (flood, wildfire, severe convective storms) relative to primary perils (major hurricanes). This matters because secondary perils are less predictable, harder to model, and often underpriced — creating adverse surprise risk. Capital allocation research: QBE's balance sheet leverage (technical reserves / equity ~3.5x) is appropriate but does create amplified downside in a stress scenario.

tags.text: Contradicts T1 (cycles do not persist indefinitely)

cards.source: Journal of Risk and Insurance; Journal of Financial Economics; Harrington & Danzon (2001); Swiss Re Economic Research

cards.title: 8. Media & Social
cards.finding: FY25 results coverage was unambiguously positive. The AFR, Bloomberg, and Reuters all led with the COR beat and 8.6% share price gain. Commentary framed the result as a vindication of Andrew Horton's transformation strategy and the exit from underperforming lines (US run-off, LMI). Social media/retail sentiment: QBE is primarily an institutional stock with limited retail following, so social signals are noisy. Key narrative in financial media: the debate is now whether QBE's COR improvement is structural (new management + portfolio quality) or cyclical (hard market will revert). The 8.6% rally on results day suggests the market was positioned conservatively and has been rewarded for patience.

tags.text: Neutral on T4 (cycle debate in media)

cards.source: AFR; Bloomberg; Reuters; QBE ASX Announcement 20 February 2026

cards.title: 9. Leadership & Governance
cards.finding: Andrew Horton (CEO, joined 2021) is the key transformation catalyst. His tenure has been defined by: (1) exiting non-core businesses (US LMI, North American run-off); (2) instilling underwriting discipline across all divisions; (3) improving the investment portfolio quality and duration management. The board has strong insurance industry experience. Key governance concerns: (1) North America was QBE's most troubled segment under prior management — whether the cultural change is complete or partially cosmetic remains to be seen; (2) crop insurance (US) is a segment with weather-driven volatility that is hard for management to control; (3) QBE's remuneration framework is now tied to COR outperformance, aligning incentives with disciplined underwriting.
cards.tension: The transformation story is compelling but 4 years old — the market has largely priced in Horton's track record. The next test is whether the discipline holds when the market softens and the temptation to chase volume emerges.

rows: Former CEO, Beazley (Lloyd's insurer); 30 years insurance experience
Former CFO, Prudential plc; capital markets expertise

tags.text: Neutral on T4 (transformation not fully tested through full cycle)

cards.source: QBE Annual Report; ASX Director disclosures; AFR executive profile

cards.title: 10. Ownership & Capital Flows
cards.finding: QBE is a well-held institutional stock. Top shareholders include: BlackRock (~6%), Vanguard (~5%), Australian institutional managers (AustralianSuper, UniSuper). No single dominant insider. Capital management: QBE has been an active share buyback participant, reducing share count from ~1.5B to ~1.39B over the past 5 years. DPS growth of 25% and a potential for buybacks if capital remains above target PCA ratio. Short interest: approximately 1-2% of free float — not a heavily shorted stock. Index inclusion: QBE is a large constituent of the S&P/ASX 200 Financials index, with passive fund demand serving as a reliable buyer.

tags.text: Neutral on T4 (no major selling signals)

cards.source: ASX substantial holder notices; ASIC short position reports; QBE Annual Report

discriminators.intro: Three data points have high diagnosticity for QBE's competing hypotheses. The 2026 North Atlantic hurricane season is the single most important external variable. COR trajectory and commercial insurance pricing are the most important operational indicators.

rows.evidence: FY26 North Atlantic hurricane season (June-November 2026). Losses above US$1B net would challenge T1; losses below US$600M would confirm it.
rows.discriminatesBetween: T1 (COR sustains <94%) vs T3 (cat season overwhelms) and T4 (cycle reversal accelerated)

rows.evidence: 1H FY26 COR guidance update (August 2026). Whether management upgrades or downgrades the 93.5-95.5% COR guidance range.
rows.discriminatesBetween: T1 (underwriting quality structural) vs T4 (cycle mean reversion beginning)

rows.evidence: Commercial insurance pricing surveys (Q1-Q2 2026). CIAB, Aon, and Marsh quarterly pricing indices. Pricing must remain above +2% to sustain T1.
rows.discriminatesBetween: T1 (hard market continues) vs T4 (cycle turning)

rows.evidence: US Federal Reserve rate decisions (2026). Rate cuts reduce investment portfolio reinvestment yield; important for T2 valuation.
rows.discriminatesBetween: T2 (investment income sustains) vs T4 (dual headwind: cycle + rates)

discriminators.nonDiscriminating: "QBE is a global insurer" (obvious, priced in) • "Hard market is good for insurers" (generic sector tailwind, not QBE-specific) • "Andrew Horton is a good CEO" (priced into the transformation narrative) • "Climate change increases cat losses" (structural multi-decade trend, not FY26-specific signal)

tripwires.intro: Three revision conditions. The catastrophe season is the highest-conviction external trigger. Premium cycle pricing data and Fed rate decisions are the key internal monitors.

cards.name: North Atlantic Hurricane Season

conditions.if: If North Atlantic season below historical average and QBE net cat losses <US$600M
conditions.then: T1 strengthens materially. COR likely tracks toward 91-92% for FY26. Market upgrades earnings estimates. T3 eliminated for the year.

conditions.if: If QBE net cat losses exceed US$1B by August 2026
conditions.then: T3 activated. FY26 COR likely to breach 97%. T1 weakens; market reassesses whether FY25 was a cyclical peak. Stock may de-rate 10-15%.

cards.source: Source: QBE ASX announcements; Colorado State University seasonal forecast; Swiss Re Cat Update

cards.name: Commercial Insurance Pricing Surveys

conditions.if: If CIAB Q1 2026 survey shows commercial pricing above +3% across US property and specialty
conditions.then: T1 confirmed for H1 FY26. Hard market durability is stronger than the cycle-mean-reversion thesis. T4 weakens.

conditions.if: If commercial pricing turns negative in any major line by Q2 2026
conditions.then: T4 begins to strengthen. Softening cycle commencing earlier than expected. Investment case requires reassessment.

cards.source: Source: CIAB Commercial Lines Survey; Aon Global Market Insights; Marsh Global Insurance Market Index

cards.name: 1H FY26 Results — COR Tracking

conditions.if: If 1H FY26 COR reported below 92% despite normal catastrophe activity
conditions.then: T1 confirmed as structural improvement. Market upgrades FY26 and FY27 estimates. Potential re-rating above 13x PE.

conditions.if: If 1H FY26 COR above 96% or reserve strengthening in North America casualty
conditions.then: T4 strengthens. North America problems re-emerging. Transformation thesis requires reassessment. Stock likely to de-rate toward A$18-19.

cards.source: Source: QBE 1H FY26 Results ASX Announcement

couldntAssess: North America reserve adequacy: Detailed segment-level reserve development for US casualty (long-tail) lines is not separately disclosed in the ASX release. Adverse development here is the key downside tail risk that cannot be fully assessed from public data.

Reinsurance programme details: The exact structure of QBE's catastrophe reinsurance and retrocession treaties is not publicly disclosed. Net retention limits post-reinsurance are critical for estimating downside from a severe cat year.

Forward pricing mix: Whether FY26 GWP growth is being achieved by maintaining existing pricing or by writing new riskier business at elevated rates — cannot be assessed without granular underwriting data.
2026 hurricane season track: This is unknowable; the key exogenous variable for the investment case.
gaps.analyticalLimitations: Hypothesis survival scores (T1: 40%, T2: 30%, T3: 30%, T4: 25%) reflect current evidence weighting. T1 scores highest because FY25 data is strongly confirmatory and management commentary supports the structural underwriting improvement thesis. T3 and T4 reflect genuine tail risks from the insurance cycle and catastrophe exposure respectively. The close score between T1 and T3/T4 reflects the binary nature of insurance — one bad cat year or cycle turn would materially change the investment case.

trend.structure: Stock gapped +8.6% on FY25 results (20 Feb 2026) from ~A$20.05, breaking above the 12-month trading range. Prior trend was sideways A$18.50-A$21.00 with no clear direction.

support.method: Pre-results close; previous resistance now support

priorSpikes.context: 52-week high; market pricing in hard market optimism
52-week low; cat season fears and rate cut expectations

inflectionPoints.event: 52-week low; cat season fears + rate cut expectations
Recovery begins; cat season ends without major QBE losses
FY25 results breakout: +8.6% on COR 91.9% beat

footer.disclaimer: This report does not constitute personal financial advice. Continuum Intelligence synthesises cross-domain evidence using the Analysis of Competing Hypotheses (ACH) methodology. All factual claims are sourced from ASX filings, company accounts, broker consensus data, and publicly available information. This report does not contain buy, sell, or hold recommendations, price targets, or valuation models.
